Question: (Java) Iterating over a Vector<String[]>, why is .next() an Object, not a String[]?: :In Java, when you iterator over a Vector<String[]>, why is .next() an Object that needs to be casted to String[], to use each element as a String[]?EDIT:Here is my code:    Iterator itr = getIdAndName().iterator();    while( itr.hasNext() ) {        String[] stringArray = (String[])itr.next();        String id = stringArray[0];        String name = stringArray[1];        System.out.println(id + ": " + name);    }getIdAndName() returns Vector<String[]>.

Question: (Java) Iterating over a Vector<String[]>, why is .next() an Object, not a String[]?: :In Java, when you iterator over a Vector<String[]>, why is .next() an Object that needs to be casted to String[], to use each element as a String[]?EDIT:Here is my code:    Iterator itr = getIdAndName().iterator();    while( itr.hasNext() ) {        String[] stringArray = (String[])itr.next();        String id = stringArray[0];        String name = stringArray[1];        System.out.println(id + ": " + name);    }getIdAndName() returns Vector<String[]>.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: String[] stringArray = (String[])itr.next();
<<<explanation>>>: The .next() method returns an Object, so it needs to be casted to String[] to use each element as a String[].

A: The .next() method returns an Object, so it needs to be casted to String[] to use each element as a String[].
